Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps L Compressible Flow Water Table

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The learning innovation developed at the University of California Davis (UC Davis) includes an in-house built water table, relevant wing models, and educational material. The project intends to scale the innovation to high school, community college and university education. The hydraulic analogy is between water flow with a free surface and two-dimensional compressible gas flow. The concept of hydraulic analogy demonstrated in the water table can serve as a great analogy not only for airplane wings but also rocket nozzles, wind turbines and many other flow related phenomena. The experiment is based on a well-known analogy between waves in compressible two dimensional flow of air to the surface waves of a shallow water layer over a flat surface. The innovation will be used in the course to demonstrate to students the hydraulic analogy using inexpensive tools.

The hypothesis of this project is that the water table is a useful invention to reinforce high school and community college education. The hypothesis will be tested by conducting 100 interviews with relevant and potential customers. Students who participate in active learning with hands-on experiments learn through self-discovery. This will attract students to engineering and science and provide lasting learning experiences. Systematically, they learn to change their presumptions about the phenomena in physics and discover the underlying concepts. This way of teaching will develop critical thinking among students and effectively engage them in classrooms. The team expects not only to use this tool broadly at UC Davis, but anticipates that other educational institutes will adopt this method.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we tested the hypothesis that the water table is a useful invention to high school and college education by talking to 100 potential customers. The I-Corps for Learning program is centered around an accelerated 8-week course following the lean start up method.


  The team has conducted 100 interviews using the techniques developed in the I-Corps for Learning course. After each interview, the team revisited the business model Canvas to adjust the hypothesis based on the data collected from the interviews.  The objective of the course is to develop a go or no-go decision on the business model based on the customer interviews. 


The course helped the team to develop the entrepreneur mind set needed to successfully sustain an invention. We changed our interview approach from “it is all about us” to “it is all about them”. With the help of the training provided by the teaching team, we also changed the type of questions asked in the interviews from close ended questions to open ended questions. For instance, we avoided asking questions similar to “do you like our invention?” and “how much would you pay for it?” and instead used questions similar to “tell us about your biggest challenges in the lab?” and “do you think of anything that could make students understand things better?”. The process helped us to better understand the customers’ needs and understand the landscape surrounding the water table experiment.  


The team targeted the following customer segments: 1- High School Physics Teachers, 2 - Community Physics Teachers, 3 - University Physics Professors, 4 - Fluid Dynamics Professors, 5 - Experimental Mechanical Engineering Professors, 6 - Museums, and 7 - Educational Tool Suppliers. We started our customer discovery by interviewing Physics instructors on various levels. However, we realized soon we needed to pivot to another customer segment. We came to this realization because the majority of Physics instructors mentioned “it will be cool to have one” (which does not reflect a direct need). We also realized that the topic of shockwave and expansion fan is not part of the required curriculum for high school students. Consequently, we changed our focus to Fluid Dynamics and Experimental Professors and got many comments such as “why would I buy it from you and not build it myself?”  and “we design and build everything in house”.


The following conclusions were drawn based on the customer interviews. Aerospace Museums are interested but the market size is too small. Physics teachers do not use many demonstrations for engineering concepts and they often do not even cover the topic of shockwaves and expansion fans. Fluid Dynamics and Experimental Professors tend to build their demos in house. Only few Fluid Dynamics and Experimental Professors showed interest in buying a water table. Educational tool suppliers are interested but intellectual property needs to be protected first.


A successful product in the education market is the one that has been developed based on a direct need or a request by a teacher. The team learned about developing a business model and the techniques can be applied to further develop our product. We learned that teachers have many problems and needs and the water table in its current status does not solve their problems or fill their needs.  Therefore, scaling and sustaining our product is not viable. Improvements and revisions for the water table will be required before trying to pursue commercialization.

 

 

Meanwhile, we have designed and tested a small scale version of our apparatus. This version students can build  themselves and they do not need to buy it. Also, we have written a technical paper on the subject to explain the theoretical aspects of the theory behind the experiment and the paper has been accepted for publication and it will appear in International Journal of Aerodynamics (IJAD). We have sent a copy and the link to NSF and it is included in the final report.

 

The team has attended the Annual Meeting for Physics Teachers in Sacramento and presented the water table for both students and teachers. The team has hosted the California State Summer School for Mathematics and Science (Cosmos) and presented the Water table to the high school students. The water table was part of the Design\Manufacturing Nozzles and Airfoil Shapes for Compressible Flow Visualizations course offered for Undergraduate students in the 2017 Spring Quarter at UC Davis.
